    • ISTP sampling for incomplete multivariate binary data

ISTP sampling for incomplete multivariate binary data

Source: vignettes/Sampling-sat.Rmd
Sampling-sat.Rmd
library(pimbayes)
#> Loading required package: JuliaCall
#> Loading required package: rje
#> Loading required package: rjags
#> Loading required package: coda
#> Linked to JAGS 4.3.1
#> Loaded modules: basemod,bugs

Package pimbayes supports the importance sampling with transparent reparameterization and convenience priors on an example of saturated logistic regression with incomplete outcome data introduced in (Lee and Gustafson 2024).

The data have three components: the binary response variable YY, the binary independent variables ùêó=(X1,‚Ä¶,Xp)T\mathbf{X} = (X_1, \dots, X_p)^T, and the indicator variable RR, which indicates the missingness of YY. The binary variable RR is 1 when YY is observed and 00 when YY is unobserved.

To ease and simplify the calculation and structure of the model, a design matrix of ùêó\mathbf{X} and a vector ùêódes‚àà‚Ñù2p\mathbf{X}_{des}\in \mathbb{R}^{2^p} representing a row of it is used. In mathematical notation, ùêódes=(X0‚Ä¶0,‚Ä¶,X1,‚Ä¶1)\mathbf{X}_{des}= (X_{0\dots0},\dots,X_{1,\dots1}) and each entry Xi1,i2,‚Ä¶,ip=1X_{i_{1},i_{2},\dots ,i_{p}} = 1 is 1 if and only if X1=i1,X2=i2,‚Ä¶,Xp=ipX_{1} = i_1, X_2 = i_{2}, \dots, X_p = i_p.

There are multiple vectors of parameters of interest,

  • Œ±=(p0‚Ä¶0,‚Ä¶,p1‚Ä¶1)T\alpha = (p_{0\dots0}, \dots,p_{1\dots1})^T where Œ±\alpha belongs to the probability simplex on 2p2^p categories and pi1,i2,‚Ä¶,ip=Pr(X1=i1,X2=i2,‚Ä¶,Xp=ip)p_{i_{1},i_{2},\dots, i_{p}} = Pr(X_{1} = i_1, X_2 = i_{2}, \dots, X_p = i_p);

  • Œ≤‚àà‚Ñù2p;\beta \in \mathbb{R}^{2^p};

  • Œ≥‚àà‚Ñù2p;\gamma \in \mathbb{R}^{2^p};

  • Œ¥‚àà‚Ñù2p.\delta \in \mathbb{R}^{2^p}.

Finally, the model is specified with

$$\begin{align} \mathbf{X}_{des} &\sim Multinom(\alpha,1) \\ (Y \mid \mathbf{X}_{des}) &\sim Bern(\mathop{\mathrm{expit}}(\mathbf{X}_{des} {\beta}));\\ (R \mid \mathbf{X}_{des}, Y = 0) & \sim Bern(\mathop{\mathrm{expit}}(\mathbf{X}_{des} \gamma));\\ (R \mid \mathbf{X}_{des}, Y = 1) & \sim Bern(\mathop{\mathrm{expit}}(\mathbf{X}_{des} (\mathop{\mathrm{expit}}(\mathop{\mathrm{logit}}(\gamma+\delta))))).$ \end{align}$$

Priors for these parameters are Œ±‚àºDir(ùüè2p),Œ≤i‚àºUnif(0,1)(i=0,‚Ä¶,2p‚àí1),Œ≥i‚àºUnif(0,1)(i=0,‚Ä¶,2p‚àí1),Œ¥i‚àºNormal(0,œÉ2)(i=0,‚Ä¶,2p‚àí1).\begin{equation} \begin{aligned} \alpha & \sim Dir(\mathbf{1}_{2^p}), & \\ \beta_{i} & \sim Unif(0,1) & (i = 0, \dots ,2^p-1), \\ \gamma_{i} & \sim Unif(0,1) & (i = 0, \dots ,2^p-1), \\ \delta_{i} & \sim Normal(0, \sigma^2) & (i = 0, \dots ,2^p-1). \end{aligned} \end{equation}

Data

Two mock datasets are available, small_sat and sat. The codes for creating the mock data are also available in the folder data-raw. Data small_sat is created from a small simulation with n=100n =100 and p=2p =2.

data(small_sat)
head(small_sat$x)
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
#> [1,]    1    0    0    0
#> [2,]    0    0    1    0
#> [3,]    0    0    1    0
#> [4,]    0    0    1    0
#> [5,]    0    0    1    0
#> [6,]    0    0    0    1
head(small_sat$y)
#> [1] NA NA  1  1 NA  1

JAGS Code 

jags_code  <- "
model{
for (i in 1:n) {
    x[i, 1:p2] ~ dmulti(px[1:p2],1)
    y[i] ~ dbern(inprod(x[i,1:p2], py_x[1:p2]))
    r[i] ~ dbern(pr[i])
    pr[i] <- (y[i]) * inprod(x[i,1:p2], pr_xy1[1:p2]) + abs(y[i]-1) * inprod(x[i,1:p2], pr_xy0[1:p2])
}
for(i in 1:p2){
    pr_xy1[i] <- ilogit(log_or_r[i] + logit(pr_xy0[i]))
}
  px[1:p2] ~ ddirich(Int64wrapper(ones(p2)))
  for(i in 1:p2) {
      py_x[i] ~ dunif(0, 1)
      pr_xy0[i] ~ dunif(0, 1)
      log_or_r[i] ~ dnorm(0, tau)
    }
}"

Sampling

When data and JAGS code are given with the desired posterior sample size, the function sampling() will return posterior samples along with ESS.

n = length(small_sat$r)
p = log2(dim(small_sat$x)[2])
sigma = 0.5 # Hyperparameter
data <- c(small_sat, list(n = n, p2 = 2^p, tau = 1/sigma^2))
results = sampling(jags_code, data, type = "sat", N = 1000)
results$ess
#> [1] 727
head(results$samples[,1:7],3)
#>       px[2] px[3] px[4] py_x[1] py_x[2] py_x[3] py_x[4]
#> [1,] 0.0729 0.507 0.191   0.309  0.0286  0.0627   0.564
#> [2,] 0.0488 0.599 0.148   0.139  0.0109  0.3711   0.546
#> [3,] 0.0358 0.499 0.281   0.216  0.0098  0.2332   0.469
head(results$samples[,8:11],3)
#>      pr_xy0[1] pr_xy0[2] pr_xy0[3] pr_xy0[4]
#> [1,]     0.385     0.318     0.314     0.804
#> [2,]     0.289     0.193     0.346     0.881
#> [3,]     0.506     0.390     0.320     0.889
head(results$samples[,12:15],3)
#>      log_or_r[1] log_or_r[2] log_or_r[3] log_or_r[4]
#> [1,]     0.18049      -0.961       0.426      0.2095
#> [2,]     0.00657      -0.217      -0.415     -0.0336
#> [3,]     0.14031       0.723       0.592     -0.4316
